user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY) && defined(HAVE_GETPID)
  /* Glibc style */
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    cpu_set_t cur_set;
    if (0 == sched_getaffinity (getpid (), sizeof (cur_set), &cur_set))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT
      ret = CPU_COUNT (&cur_set);
#else  /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
      unsigned int i;
      ret = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE; ++i)
      {
        if (CPU_ISSET (i, &cur_set))
          ++ret;
      }
      if (0 == ret)
        ret = -1;
#endif /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
    }
  }
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Use 256 times larger size than size for default maximum CPU number.
       Hopefully it would be enough even for exotic situations. */
    static const unsigned int set_size_cpus = 256 * CPU_SETSIZE;
    const size_t set_size_bytes = CPU_ALLOC_SIZE (set_size_cpus);
    cpu_set_t *p_set;

    p_set = CPU_ALLOC (set_size_cpus);
    if (NULL != p_set)
    {
      if (0 == sched_getaffinity (getpid (), set_size_bytes, p_set))
      {
#ifndef MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (set_size_bytes, p_set);
#else  /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (set_size_cpus, p_set);
#endif /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
      }
      CPU_FREE (p_set);
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S */
#endif /* HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY && HAVE_GETPID */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_:
#define HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY 1
...
#define HAVE_GETPID 1
...
#define HAVE_CPU_COUNT 1
...
#define HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S 1
...
#define CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE CPU_SETSIZE
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no explicit use of known compiler language extensions in the provided source fragment. The code does not contain GCC/Clang extensions such as inline asm, nested functions, statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, __attribute__ annotations, labels-as-values, extended vector types, or other vendor-specific keywords. The constructs present are standard C and POSIX usages: static function, block-scope static const, standard control flow, calls to POSIX APIs (sched_getaffinity, getpid), and use of cpu_set_t and CPU_* macros provided by libc. 

Notes on potential false positives that do not require investigation here:
- CPU_COUNT, CPU_COUNT_S, CPU_ALLOC, CPU_ALLOC_SIZE, CPU_FREE, CPU_ISSET, CPU_SETSIZE, cpu_set_t and related macros/types are library/glibc interfaces; their use in source code is not by itself a language extension. If needed, their expansions could be reviewed to ensure they do not expand to compiler-specific extensions, but there is no evidence in the shown code that they do.
- Preprocessor conditionals (#if defined(...)) and the use of feature-test macros (HAVE_*) are standard portable techniques and not language extensions.

If you want absolute assurance that no language extensions are used by macros or included headers, inspect the definitions/headers of the CPU_* and CPU_ALLOC* symbols and the sched_getaffinity/getpid declarations; only those macro/header definitions could hide compiler-specific extensions. Based solely on the provided function body and symbols, there are no explicit language extensions to report.
